newsitem.title: UK: UK industry has cheaper gas than competitors - survey.
newsitem.headline: UK industry has cheaper gas than competitors - survey.

text.p: Britain's industrial gas users saw their gas bills creep higher last year, but still enjoy cheaper gas than the rest of Western Europe and North America, a survey by U.K. consultants National Utility Services (NUS) revealed.

The 13-country survey showed a year-on-year increase in U.K. business user gas prices of more than five percent in 1996 to 0.6 pence per kilowatt hour (p/kwh), a sharp reversal from the 40 percent slide registered in 1995.
"The honeymoon period that British industry has enjoyed with the injection of competition into the market is over," said NUS director Andrew Johns.
Prices shown in the survey were the average of independent suppliers and British Gas for contracts renewed on September 1, 1996.
A recovery in spot market prices, the tightening of margins by independent suppliers and the consumption of surplus North Sea gas combined to keep the heat under end-user prices, said the NUS report.
Nevertheless, British industry still pays less for gas than its competitors in Western Europe, where gas market deregulation is proceeding at a slower pace.
And Britain even enjoys lower prices than in the fully-competitive gas markets of the United States and Canada, the survey said.
Italy topped the table in 1996, with industrial customers paying an average of 2.31 p/kwh for gas, almost four times as much as British consumers.
Spanish gas prices averaged 1.58 p/kwh, while prices in the Netherlands, itself a large gas producer, were 1.47 p/kwh -- more than double U.K. prices.
In France, gas bills averaged 1.40 p/kwh, and 1.37 p/kwh in Germany. Belgium boasted the cheapest gas prices in continental Western Europe at 1.21 p/kwh.
Despite a leap of more than 14 percent last year, U.S. prices still averaged below 1 p/kwh at 0.88 p/kwh, while Canadian prices hovered slightly above U.K. prices at 0.68 p/kwh.
